column1: '''Concerning ... 'The Hoard'''' is the title of a manuscript by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]]
column2: enclosed by him in a [[Letter to Eileen Elgar (5 March 1964)|1964 letter to Eileen Elgar]] (together with [[Kinship of the Half-elven]]).

column3: gives an outline of '[[The Silmarillion]]' by relating his poem ''[[The Hoard]]'' to this still unpublished work. An extract from the manuscript appeared in ''[[Sotheby's English Literature and English History 6-7 December 1984]]''
column4: and was reproduced in [[Beyond Bree May 1985|''Beyond Bree'' May 1985]].<ref>{{CG|C}}

column2: [[Wayne G. Hammond]] and [[Christina Scull]] have commented that:

column1: {{blockquote|Christina examined the manuscript on one of the pre-auction viewing days at [[Sotheby's]]
column2: and found that it gives some indication of Tolkien's then-current thoughts on some parts of ''The Silmarillion''. She had just read ''[[The Book of Lost Tales Part Two|The Book of Lost Tales
column3: Part Two]]'' (published 16 August 1984) and had reviewed it for ''[[Beyond Bree]]''
column4: so that text was fresh in her mind; and in relation to it
column5: she noted developments by Tolkien since the ''Lost Tales'' as well as differences from the published ''Silmarillion''. With regard to the [[ruin of Doriath]]
column6: the story told in the 1964 manuscript is closer to the ''[[Quenta Noldorinwa]]'' (not published until 1986) than to ''[[The Nauglafring]]'' in ''The Book of Lost Tales''
column7: but differs in some respects from any published version — for instance
column8: before beginning work on the treasure
column9: the dwarves agree to accept a payment of a tenth of the unwrought metals. [[Thingol]]
column12: with Tolkien giving two possible reasons why the dwarves were able to pass the [[Girdle of Melian]].

column1: ''Presumably Tolkien made no file copy of this manuscript
column2: and otherwise left no record in his papers to assist [[Christopher Tolkien|Christopher]] in his work on ''The Silmarillion''. A few years ago
column3: Christina sent Christopher a copy of the notes she made at Sotheby's ...
column4: which he found very interesting. The manuscript and covering letter sold for £2
column6: presumably a bookseller acting for a buyer
column7: and we have seen no sign of it in later years
column8: in public or private collections or in the marketplace.''|<ref name=Plaza/>}}
